awd_titl_txt: RAPID proposal: Rapid seismic response to the July 2019 Mw 7.1 and 6.4 doublet near Ridgecrest, Southern California
awd_abstract_narration:
This RAPID project is a seismic response to the two July 2019 Ridgecrest earthquakes in southern California. The earthquakes occurred close to the southern San Andreas fault and the Garlock fault. This is a heavily populated area that could sustain significant damage if earthquakes happened on those faults. While Ridgecrest is less populated, understanding these earthquakes can help us to better understand the seismic hazard more broadly in southern California, it can also help us to understand how large earthquake evolve and what physics governs these events. This experiment will rapidly deploy 20 seismic instruments around the earthquake ruptures. These additional stations will improve our ability to record aftershocks from the two mainshocks. The broader impacts of the project include support for students to be trained in scientific response to earthquakes and an improved understanding of seismic hazard in southern California. The data from this experiment will be made publicly available through the seismic data facility at IRIS.

This deployment of 20 seismic stations around the epicenter of the Mw 7.1 and Mw6.4 Ridgecrest earthquakes will be used to determine the detailed fault structure, possible earthquake triggering, aftershock occurrence. The project will deploy a combination of short period and strong ground motion stations in collaboration with the USGS. Results may also inform high resolution seismic velocity structure, postseismic deformation and the evolution of stress in the region. Ultimately this may improve understanding of seismic potential on the Garlock and San Andreas faults which are in close proximity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

por.por_cntn:
Major goal of this project is to rapidly deploy a temporary seismic network around the rupture area of magnitude 7.1 Ridgecrest earthquake in July 2019. This network, combined with an existing network, enables us to collect time-sensitive invaluable seismic data only produced during an active aftershock sequence. This data help image aftershock activity in a very high resolution potentially providing new insights into the physics of earthquake rupture, stress evolution after a relatively large earthquake, and related seismic hazards.

We have installed more than 20 seismic stations as part of a carefully designed network. The design considers the existing seismic stations nearby and fill in the gaps in a way optimal for earthquake detection and location. The first station is installed within one day of the mainshock. The stations are operational for up to one year. They are serviced multiple times to maintain smooth operation of the network. We have retrieved the last station of the network in July 2020.

After end of the data collection, we have converted the data into a format usable by the community -- scientists, educators and general public. We send the data to a central data repository center for permanent archival. This data is currently available to download for anyone who wants to. This rich and unique data is providing science community an opportunity to look into the details of aftershock activity and study earthquake physics and associated hazards. The knowledge we gain from such studies will help us better understand earthquake physics, related hazards, and hence better prepare us for future damaging earthquakes.

This project helps a young geophysicist (principal investigator) to become a more mature scientist and provides opportunity to educate, mentor and guide multiple graduate students in a minority-serving institutions. It involves training of related hardware (seismic sensors, dataloggers) and software that allow us to record the data and archive it using a set standards such that it serves the global community of scientists, educators and general population for the years to come.
